workday.question: How would you describe your typical workday?

devices.question: How often do you use digital devices in the hour before bed?

bedtime.question: What time do you usually go to bed?

goal.question: What is your primary goal today?

timeToSleep.question: On average, how long does it take you to fall asleep?

nightWaking.question: How often do you wake up during the night?

afternoonCrash.question: Do you experience "3:00 PM sleepiness" (afternoon energy crash)?

racingThoughts.question: Do you experience "racing thoughts" when you lie down to sleep?

stress.question: How often do you experience stress during the week?

switchOff.question: Is it difficult for you to "switch off" work tasks once you are home?

anxiety.question: Do you have bouts of anxiety without an obvious cause?

wiredTired.question: Are you familiar with the feeling of being "wired but tired"?

silence.question: How do you feel about total silence while sleeping?

sharpNoises.question: Do sharp noises (dripping faucet, ticking clock) irritate you?

tvPodcasts.question: Have you ever tried falling asleep to the TV or podcasts?

naturalSounds.question: What type of natural sounds do you prefer?

earplugs.question: Do you use earplugs to sleep?

coffee.question: Do you drink coffee or tea in the afternoon?

exercise.question: Do you exercise late in the evening?

bedroomUse.question: Is your bedroom used only for sleep, or do you also work/eat there?

ritual.question: Are you ready to dedicate 10 minutes to a nightly sound ritual to reset your biorhythms?

info.binauralBeats: Our algorithms utilize binaural beats. When you hear different frequencies in each ear, your brain "tunes in" to them, naturally entering a state of meditation.
info.researchText: Harvard Medical School research confirms that light from devices suppresses melatonin production. However, sound can help compensate for this.
info.soundTherapy: Sound therapy creates a predictable environment that signals the amygdala (the brain's fear center) that it is time to relax
info.whiteNoise: For those with an anxious personality type, white noise is more effective than sleeping pills as it has no side effects or risk of dependency

testimonial1.title: Using Cloudnoise for 4 months!
testimonial1.text: I used to wake up at every little noise outside and spend 2 hours trying to fall back asleep. Cloudnoise literally saved my marriage—now I don't get annoyed by my husband's snoring; I simply don't hear it over the 'Brown Noise'
testimonial1.author: — Elena, 32.

productivity.title: From "Burnout" to "Productivity"
productivity.rating: Rating: 4.9/5 in App Store based on 31M reviews
productivity.text: I used CloudNoise for work. It turns out deep rain sounds increase my focus by 40%. I finish my tasks twice as fast and go to bed without the guilt of unfinished work

results.matchText: of users who successfully overcame insomnia within the first 10 days of using Cloudnoise
results.recommendation: Cloudnoise is recommended as an aid for correcting circadian rhythms

personalPlan.title: Create your personal Soundscape
personalPlan.intro: Based on your responses (specifically regarding device use and racing thoughts), we've identified that your brain needs a "sound blanket".
